tagger.tagNote: First pass; Colleen Doody, second pass 3/10/98

div.head: Speech of Hon. John L. Dawson of Pennsylvania on the State of the Union
div.excerpt: "They [the Lincoln administration] were not satisfied with passing a bill offering protection and freedom to the slaves of rebel masters who should come within our lines, not satisfied with directing the physical power of the country to the suppression of armed resistance to the authority of the Government, but they proceeded to carry the war directly against the property, the homes, the firesides of peaceful non-combatant residents of seceded States. This was in violation not only of the Federal Constitution, but of every principle of public law."
div.summary: A former member of the Pennsylvania state legislature provides a history of the sectional conflict and condemns the Lincoln administration's subsequent execution of the war.

page.pageNote: Dawson's speech is the only article on this page.

div.head: Mr. Grinnell's Speech
div.summary: Reprints a "venomous" speech given by a Republican congressman that condemns all Democrats.
Suggests that General Fremont's new assignment to command the Department of the South is an attempt by Lincoln to get rid of a rival presidential candidate.

div.head: Gen. McClellan and His Enemies
div.summary: Argues that the persecution campaign waged against General McClellan is evidence of his popularity with the people.

div.head: Mr. Dawson's Speech
div.summary: Applauds John L. Dawson's speech as a sound defense of the Constitution.

div.head: Miscegenation
div.commentary: "Will it be made a plank in Mr. Lincoln's next platform?"
div.summary: Suggests that interracial sex is not condemned in the Bible.

div.head: Sound Letter from Mr. Bates
div.summary: Prints a letter from Attorney General Edward Bates that questions whether Republican policies are preserving the Union.

div.head: The Florida Atrocity
div.summary: Provides more documents that reveal cowardice on the part of Lincoln and Union soldiers in Florida.

div.head: Kentucky
div.summary: Notes that news of a Kentucky delegation headed for the Democratic Convention has incited indignation among Republicans.

div.head: A Railroad Meeting
div.summary: Reports on a recent meeting of a group to oversee the construction of the Southern Pennsylvania Railroad. James Kelly was elected chairman and Joseph Hunter secretary.

div.head: The Next Draft
div.summary: Explains the procedures that will be followed in the upcoming draft.

div.head: Borough Extension
div.excerpt: "The demand for new houses has never been greater in our town than the present."

transcript.p: The demand for new houses has never been greater in our town than the present. Families from abroad, not a few, have in vain searched for houses to rent. We must have more houses built, and we are therefore glad to hear that a number of building lots on Second street and on Catharine street (to be extended through Dr. Schneck's beautiful lots,) are now in the market. The owner of these lots has a draught prepared of the plot of ground, and has fixed a reasonable price on each lot, with easy terms of payment. Now is the time to select the choice sites. There can be no doubt, that in a short time we shall see half a score of fine houses erected in that eligible part of town.

div.summary: Applauds the sale of house lots on Second Street and explains that the growing demand for housing in town is coming from new immigrants.

div.head: Be Vaccinated
div.summary: Urges readers not to delay in obtaining a small pox vaccination.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Rev. S. McHenry married Emanuel Eppleman, Company G, 183th Pennsylvania Regiment, and Georgiana Neff on March 13.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Rev. Dr. Schneck married William S. Gearhart and Mary Ann Clorin on February 25.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 20, Rev. Dr. Schneck married William Weston and Rebecca Lawrence.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Rev. J. Dickson married Thomas P. Parmer and Sarah E. Bickley on March 17.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 20, Rev. William McElroy married Isaac P. Reene, of Scranton, and Emma C. Hart.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 22, Rev. S. McHenry married David W. Felker, of Mt. Morris, Ogle County, Illinois, and Lila Taylor, daughter of ex-Sheriff Taylor of Chambersburg.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 21, Rev. Thomas Barnhart married William Armstrong and Elizabeth Kiplinger, of Hagerstown, Maryland.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Mrs. Susannah Miller died on February 29 at age 69.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Ellsworth McClellan Byers died on March 6 at age 1 year, 3 months.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Anna B. Caufman, wife of A. D. Caufman, Esq., died on March 19.

div.head: List of Causes for Trial
div.summary: Cases that will be heard beginning in the April 1864 term of the Court of Common Pleas are: John & Sol Ely vs. Franklin Funk; Michael Zellers vs. James Rule; Jacob Overcash vs. William A. Haselet; Matthias Phillipy vs. John Ashway; S & M Pennock & Co. vs. William Reber; Solomon Allison vs. Uriah P. Smith; James S. Ross' Executrix vs. J. S. Rosenbury, Ex'r; Solomon Baker vs. Philip Kyner's Adm'r.

div.head: Presidential Order
div.summary: Publishes a copy of President Lincoln's March 14 order for a draft of 200,000 more men.

div.head: Congressional
div.summary: Summarizes recent proceedings of the Confederate Congress, including the consideration of a petition from Louisiana blacks asking for a vote in the reorganization of that state.

page.pageNote: Reports of troop movement and skirmishing in Louisville, Chattanooga, and Newbern, North Carolina, column 1, classified ads, columns 2-6
